Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará: 10 cajas de galletas, 4 cajas de chocolate, 3 bolsas de chupetines, 4 paquetes de gaseosa, 5 cajas de chicle, 6 paquetes de frugos en botella, 4 cajas de frugos en caja. Ella tiene 34 años de edad, es casada y tiene 3 hijos, su esposo trabaja en construcción ambos trabajan para educar a sus hijos y mantener su hogar.

loans.use: With the loan, she will purchase merchandise to sell

loans.name: Benita

texts.es:
Mrs. Benita is a member of the Communal Bank "Villa Turística D. Catac II". She sells groceries and candy for a living; her business is located at the Catac market, in the district of Catac, Recuay province, department of Ancash. With the loan of $750 USD, which will be paid in 8 installments, she will purchase: 2 sacks of sugar, 2 sacks of rice, 1 box of oil, 1 pack of salt, 1 bag of semolina, 4 packs of 1.5 liter sodas, 4 bags of noodles, 3 large packs of yogurt, 3 small packs of yogurt, 3 boxes of shampoo, 2 bags of detergent, and 4 packs of toilet paper. She is 48 years old; she is married and has 6 children who are adults and are independent. Her husband picks up occasional jobs.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Benita, pertenece al Banco Comunal Villa Turística D. Catac II, se dedica a la venta D. Abarrotes y Golosinas, su negocio esta ubicado en el mercado D. Catac del distrito Catac y provincia D. Recuay, departamento D. Ancash. Con el préstamo D. S/. 2,000.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 8 cuotas, comprará 2 sacos D. azúcar, 2 sacos D. arroz, 1 caja D. aceite, 1 paquete D. sal, 1 bolsa D. sémola, 4 paquetes D. gaseosa D. 1 ½ litro, 4 bolsas D. fideos, 3 paquetes D. yogur granD., 3 paquetes D. yogur chico, 3 cajas D. shampoo, 2 bolsas D. detergente, 4 paquetes D. papel higiénico. Ella tiene 48 años D. edad, es casada y tiene 6 hijos ya son mayores e independientes, su esposo tiene trabajos eventuales.

loans.use: With the loan, she will purchase merchandise to sell

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es:
Mrs. Yolanda is a member of the Communal Bank "Señor D. Mayo". She owns a hardware store which is based out of her home in the district of Catac, Recuay province, department of Ancash. With the loan of $575 USD, which will be paid in 6 installments, she will purchase 20 units of piping, 50 bags of cement, 12 brooms, and 5 rolls of barb wire. She is 49 years old; she is married and has one son. Her husband is a farmer and together they help each other to cover household expenses and their son's education.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Yolanda, pertenece al Banco Comunal Señor D. Mayo, cuenta con una ferretería, su negocio sé ubicado en su domicilio del distrito D. Catac y provincia D. Recuay, departamento D. Ancash. Con este préstamo D. S/. 1,500.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, comprará 20 unidades D. tubo, 50 bolsas D. cemento, 12 unidades D. escoba, 5 rollos D. alambre púa. Ella tiene 49 años D. edad, es casada y tiene 1 hijo, su esposo se dedica a la agricultura y juntos se apoyan con los gastos D. su hogar y la educación D. su hijo.

loans.use: With the loan, she will purchase more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
Mrs. Victoria is a member of the Communal Bank "Señor D. Mayo". She sells groceries for a living; her business based out of her home in the district of Catac, Recuay province, department of Ancash. With this loan of $575 US, which she will repay in 6 installments, she will purchase: 2 sacks of rice, 2 sacks of sugar, 2 boxes of tuna fish, 2 boxes of oil, 1 box of milk, 3 boxes of soda (individual serving size), 3 packs of 3 liter sodas. She is 58 years old; she is married and has 6 children. Her husband is a farmer and both help each other in order to cover household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Victoria, pertenece al Banco Comunal Señor D. Mayo, se dedica a la venta D. Abarrotes, su negocio sé ubicado en su domicilio del distrito D. Catac y provincia D. Recuay, departamento D. Ancash. Con este préstamo D. S/. 1,500.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, comprará: 2 sacos D. arroz, 2 sacos D. azúcar, 2 cajas D. atún, 2 cajas D. aceite, 1 caja D. leche, 3 cajas D. gaseosa personal, 3 paquetes D. gaseosa D. 3 litros. Ella tiene 58 años D. edad, es casada y tiene 6 hijos, su esposo se dedica a la agricultura y ambos se apoyan con los gastos del hogar.

loans.use: With this loan, she will purchase more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.en:
R. Consuelo S. has a business manufacturing and selling shoes in La Esperanza, a suburb of Trujillo, La Libertad Region.  R. works with her husband and they specialize in women’s shoes made of leather and synthetic materials.  She has a lifetime of experience and many loyal customers.  She sells most of her shoes in Tumbes, a northern zone of Peru.

R. is 53 years old, happily married with 6 children.  Of her 6 children, four are still dependent on her.  She loves working from home where she can spend time with her family.  All of her family helps with the business but R. saves carefully so she can send her children to University so they can have more opportunities in life than she had.

A member of the community bank Mujeres Valerosas II, R. is requesting a loan of $300 to repay over 6 months. She will buy extra leather and synthetic material.  In the future she dreams of having a large shoe factory.

loans.use: To buy extra leather and synthetic material

loans.name: Señor De Santiago Group

texts.es:
At early hours of the morning, still at dawn, in the "Las Mañaneras" market (The Early Risers market, which is so named because products are only sold there between 5-10 a.m.), located on Tumusia street in La Paz, ten women sell clothing, which they make and design themselves. They sell these products both retail and wholesale. These women form part of the "Señor de Santiago" association, which belongs to the main group of Villa Tejana. They work in a disciplined way, and they say that they need to increase their capital to purchase special machinery and to expand their shops so they can increase their production and obviously their profits for the good of themselves and their large families.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

A tempranas horas de la mañana, aun de madrugada, en la feria “Las Mañaneras” (denominada así por que la venta de productos solo se la realiza de 5am a 10am) ubicada en la C. Tumusla de la ciudad de La Paz, mas de diez mujeres se dedican a la comercialización de ropa, esta, confeccionada y diseñada por ellas mismas. Productos que los venden al por mayor y menor. Estas señoras forman parte de la asociación “Señor de Santiago” que pertenece al centro focal de Villa Tejada, trabajando de manera disciplinada afirman que necesitan aumentar su capital para la compra de maquinaria especial, y para ampliar sus talleres de esta manera aumenta su producción y obviamente sus ganancias para el bien de ellas y de sus numerosas familias.

loans.use: Capital to purchase special machinery and to expand their shops

loans.name: Aboke Self-Help Group

texts.en:
Joseph O. is a young Kenyan father, aged 30, with 6 children.  He also lives with 2 orphan children of his late sister who passed away 2 years ago.

Joseph started his business 4 years ago after accumulating savings from his former workplace in a local hospital in Kisumu town.  He currently operates a small retail cereals business of maize, rice, and green grams (mung beans) that he sells to his customers in the neighborhood.  

Being the sole breadwinner for his family, Joseph has to support his children and his wife, who has a low-paying job.  With the little profit that he gets from the business, Joseph still struggles to feed,
clothe, and educate his children and to pay his house rent.  With the help of his loan, Joseph will be able to purchase more bags of different grains to enable him to increase his sales.  He also hopes to open up a cereal wholesale unit from the business profits.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Purchasing grains in bulk

payments.comment:
Dear Lender,

Aboke Self-Help Group has now repaid $86.  It is 5% complete in repaying its loan to Kiva lenders.

Thanks!
Opportunity International-WEDCO

loans.name: Bandari Artisans Self-Help Group

texts.en:
Christine A. is an average Kenyan woman, aged 27, and married with 2 children. She has been in the grocery business (fruits and vegetables) for two years. She got her capital from the small savings she obtained from participation in various women's savings cooperatives. Her business is located at a Kisumu bus terminal, and most of her clients are passengers who travel to various destinations.

Christine uses the profits from her business to feed, clothe, and educate the children, as her husband does not have a well-paying job. With the help of her loan, Christine would want to diversify her business to include juice-selling along with the green grocer business.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To diversify her business

payments.comment:
Dear Lender,

The Bandari Artisans Self-Help Group has now repaid $55 of its loan.  It is 8% complete in repaying its loan.

Thank you for your support of this group.

Sincerely,
Opportunity International-WEDCO

loans.name: Bridge Women Group

texts.en:
Leila is an average 40-year-old mother married with 4 children of her own. She also lives with 1 orphan child of her late sister.  

Leila first started business as a fish vendor, a business she did for seven years.  She started as a retailer and then gradually moved on to the wholesale fish business.  It was at this point that Leila saved money from her profits and purchased a computer.

Leila was also a member of various women's groups who undertook several projects to generate group income.  From the group profits, Leila was able to purchase another computer.  Then she decided to open up a bureau right behind her house.  She currently has two computers and a black and white printer that she uses to operate her business.  Leila provides internet, printing, and stationery services at her business.

With the help of her loan, Leila will be able to purchase a colored printer which she says will enable her be more competitive in the market.  Leila’s long term business vision is to purchase a photocopier machine for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a colored printer.

loans.name: Elishadai Self-Help Group

texts.en:
Esther A. is an average Kenyan woman aged 40 and married with 4 children. She also lives with 2 orphan children of her late brother.

Esther started operating her second-hand clothes business, commonly referred to as “Mutumba,” nine years ago because the income of her husband, who is a cobbler, was too little to support all their family's needs.

Esther is now able to purchase at least 5 bails of second-hand clothes every week to sell to her regular customers. With the little profits that she gets from the small-scale business, Esther is able to feed, clothe and educate her children. With the help of her loan, Esther hopes to purchase more bails of second-hand clothes to increase her sales.

In the future, Esther would like to open up a boutique in her home town of Luanda, in the Western part of Kenya.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Purchase bails of second-hand clothes in bulk

payments.comment:
Dear Lender,

The Elishadai Self-Help Group has now repaid $649 of its loan.  It is 56% complete in repaying.

Thank you for your support.

Sincerely,
Opportunity International-WEDCO
Partner has reported that the loan has been fully repaid.  This group has now taken out a new loan with Opportunity International-WEDCO (but not posted to Kiva for funding)

loans.name: Konyango Village Traders Self-Help Group

texts.en:
Mary A. is a young Kenyan mother, aged 30, with 2 children. She lives with 1 orphan child of her late sister who perished 2 years ago. Mary started her business 3 years ago after accumulating savings from her former work place. She currently deals in ladies' second-hand shoes but would like to diversify to children's and men’s collection as well. Being the bread winner for the family, it would enable her to support her children and her husband, who does not have a job. During the low business season, Mary is at times forced to sell fruit juice, which she makes in her house and sells to her regular customers, mostly women.

With the little profit that she gets from the business, Mary still struggles to pay the house rent and to feed, clothe and educate her children. But with the help of her loan, Mary will be able to increase her stock of shoes and increase her monthly sales. Mary’s long term business vision is to diversify her business and sell new shoes to her customers.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand shoes

payments.comment: Dear Kiva Lender, Unfortunately, the disbursement for this loan was marked late. However, Konyango Village Traders Self-Help Group has repaid $273! It is now 12% complete in its repayment. Thank you for your support of this group. Sincerely, Opportunity International-WEDCO

loans.name: Madzuu Mwenyelizi Self-Help Group

texts.en:
Jescar is a middle-aged, single mother with 6 children of her own and 3 orphans from her sister who died 4 years ago. As a single mother, Jescar has to struggle hard to ensure that she puts food on the table. She started her second-hand clothes business 5 years ago after working for a hospital in Nairobi as a cleaner. With the accumulated savings that she got from her earnings, Jescar was able to start her business with two bails of clothes. She now purchases 6 bails of second-hand clothes every week to sell to her regular customers, who are mostly women.

With the little profits that she earns, Jescar is still able to feed, clothe, and educate her children who are still quite young. With the help of the loan, Jescar will be able to purchase more bails of second-hand clothes to enable her to increase her business sales. Her long-term business vision is to diversify her business to a wholesale unit.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To purchase more bails of clothes

payments.comment: Dear Kiva Lender, Unfortunately, the disbursement for this loan was marked late. However, Madzuu Mwenyelizi Self-Help Group has repaid $124! It is now 11% complete in its repayment. Thank you for your support of this group. Sincerely, Opportunity International-WEDCO

loans.name: Furkat

texts.ru:
Furkat has been breeding cattle since he was very young. During his childhood his parents have been keeping the cattle and he learned from them. Now he has five years of experience and lives off his business and tries to develop it. At this time he has a loan to help him increase the heads of his cattle. In the spring, the cattle is in the fields, but during the winter it was much harder to keep it because of the lack of fresh grass because hay and other fodder are expensive or not enough to feed the cattle. At this time Furkat has been paying off the loan without any problems.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Фуркат разводит скот с малых лет . В детстве его родители дома содержали скот, у них он научилась разведением скота. Теперь, когда она имеет пяти летний опыт, он живет на этом бизнесе и старается развивать его. В настоящее время для того, что бы увеличить поголовья скота он получил кредит. Сейчас весной его скот пасется на пастбище, но до этого им приходилось трудно, так как зимой нет, свежей травы, а сухая трава и другие кормы, дорогие или недостаточны для поддержания скота. На данный момент он с легкостью погашает свой кредит.

loans.use: To keep livestock

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 45535

loans.name: Cheap

texts.en:
Cheap H., 56 years old, lives as a subsistence farmer in Kampong Cham province, earning $1 per day profit beyond what she uses to feed her family. Sim Srang, her husband, is a construction manager operating in another village on the other side of their province. A very experienced worker, having labored in construction since 1979, he earns $5 per day. They have six children, three of whom are already married. One of them is employed by a garment factory and earns $80 per month. Some of their other children work for their father in construction and earn $2 per day. Only one of them is still in school.

Cheap H. wants to expand her business by purchasing a cow to help her plow her fields. She works alone running the farm, so a cow could save her valuable time and increase the meager profit she can make as a farmer.

loans.use: To buy a cow.

loans.name: Fatuma's Majindecha Group

texts.en:
Fatuma is 28 years old and is married with 2 children, aged 7 and 1. She and her husband also take care of two other children, aged 16 and 9. Fatuma is a sells clothes, a business which she started in 2007. She earns a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

She is looking for this loan to buy more clothes to help jumpstart her business. She will share this loan with her group member Linda, who also sells clothes. She thanks you in advance for the loan.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Fatuma's Majindecha Group

texts.en:
Fatuma is 28 years old and is married woman with 2children, ages 7 and 1 years old. She and her husband also take care of 2 other children, ages 16 and 9 years old. Fatuma is a clothes seller, she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 8am to 18pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Linda, who has business dealing in clothes sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Somoe

texts.en:
Somoe is 25 years old and is a single woman. Somoe started selling clothes in 2007. Every day, she works from 9am to 3pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Mwanahamis

texts.en:
Mwanahamis is 38 years old and is married with three children, 16, 11and 3 years old. She and her husband also take care of two other people, aged 31 and 22.

Mwanahamis is a clothes seller, a business she has been in since 2000. She works from 9am to 6pm daily and can earn a monthly profit of about $550 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Sam S. is a 42-year-old housewife in the central Cambodian province of Kampong Cham. Her 62-year-old husband, Ang Sen, works as a security guard for a rural company, earning only $1 per day. Of their six children, only one is married and living outside the family home. Suffering from extreme poverty, the family must depend on the children to work and provide financial support. Three of them are employed in a logging factory, making $90 each per month. With this additional income Sam and her husband have invested in their younger children, sending them to school.

Because she wants her family to at least enjoy the security of a stable home, Sam’s loan would go towards constructing a well-built house on stilts to better withstand monsoons and seasonal flooding.

loans.use: To build a house.

loans.name: Khoun

texts.en: Khoun L. is a 37-year-old mother of four. She and her husband, Mom Doung, support their family by fermenting rice to produce Khmer rice wine, a traditional drink that is very popular in Kampong Cham due to its affordability and health-promoting qualities. They supplement their income by raising pigs, earning a total daily income of approximately $2.  Now Khoun L. would like to take out a loan to purchase additional pigs to breed so that she can increase her family’s income.

loans.use: To purchase pigs for breeding

loans.name: Chhoun

texts.en:
Chhoun N. is 28 years old. Although her family home is in the central province of Kampong Cham, she makes her living sea fishing from the port city of Kampong Som, which is located on the Gulf of Thailand. She earns $6 per day selling her fish in local markets. Her husband, who also had to leave Kampong Cham to find a steady job, works in Siem Reap as a blacksmith earning $3 per day. They have two young children living in Kampong Cham with their relatives, but they rarely get to see them. Unfortunately, it is not uncommon for poor families to have to separate in this way and send portions of their earnings back home in order to survive

As Kampong Som grows, fishing becomes a much more competitive enterprise, so Chhoun wants to invest in better fishing tools, including nets and bait, so that her business can stay alive. With any remaining money she will buy reserve fuel for her boat. This is a key cost to consider, as gasoline is now up to $7 per gallon in Cambodia, and rising.

loans.use: To buy fishing tools and gasoline.

loans.name: Agnes'gold E Group

texts.en:
Agnes N., age 50, is married and has 4 children (ages 30, 29, 26 and 24). She has a poultry business and a tailoring business which she began 5 years ago. She works from 8am to 6pm daily and is able to make a monthly profit of about $167.

In the past, Agnes has taken out two previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy more chicks to raise and materials for her tailoring business. She now hopes for a third loan to further expand her little poultry business. Agnes will share this loan with her subgroup members who deal in selling chickens, running a shop, and selling vegetables, fruit, and fish.

In the picture Agnes is second from left, back row, in a white skirt and red blouse.

loans.use: to buy more chicks for her little poultry business

loans.name: San

texts.en:
San S. is a 29-year-old subsistence farmer in Kampong Cham province. After feeding her family, she only makes a little less than $1 per day from her yields. Her husband farms with her and adds only $1 per day to their income. The couple has two children who they hope to someday be able to afford to send to school.

Farming is a difficult and unstable enterprise due to the fact that weather patterns have begun to behave erratically in recent years, putting most farmers under financial strain. San and her husband therefore want to branch out into raising livestock by purchasing pig food for the piglets that recently came into their possession. If they can develop this business it will lead to greater financial security and possibly education for their children.

loans.use: To buy food for raising pigs.

loans.name: Choeun

texts.en:
Choeun Y., age 30,  lives in Kampong Cham province, where she and her husband work growing rice in both the rainy and dry seasons making, on average, $3 a day.  They have three children, one of whom is a student while the other two are Y. too young to attend school.


Choeun is requesting a loan to purchase wood to repair their house, as the roof leaks during the rainy season. In the near future, she plans to raise chickens and ducks for the eggs. (Picture: husband, wife and small son)

loans.use: To purchase wood to repair her house.

loans.name: Menh

texts.en:
Menh S. is a 29-year-old garment factory worker earning $3 per day in Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Phnom Penh is full of such factories in which tens of thousands of young women work incredibly long shifts for low wages. Menh’s husband, Oun Thai, works as a taxi driver in the Skun district of Kampong Cham, their home province, earning $5 per day.

It is quite common for garment factory workers to commute from their villages, sometimes hours away, to work each morning in Phnom Penh. In order to save time and money on travel,, Menh is requesting a loan to purchase a motorbike which will enable her both to commute to work and arrive home earlier to spend time with her only child, while still making ends meet.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Um

texts.en:
Um P., age 33, (her husband is pictured) a mother of eight children, resides in Kampong Cham province where she has a business selling fruit in a busy market, earning about $2 a day. Her husband, a construction worker building houses, normally earns around $3 a day. Two of their children are married and live away from home. Another child is a horse cart driver, and two daughters sell fruits and roasted eggs, the latter one of the most popular foods in Cambodia. As well, one son works as a construction worker, while the rest stay at home, earning no profit.

Um P.’s husband would like a loan from Kiva to purchase a trailer, which will enable him to augment family income through additional jobs outside of construction.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer to earn additional income.

loans.name: Ham

texts.en:
Ham P. is a 55-year-old independent construction worker living in the Kampong Cham province of  Cambodia. He would like to apply a loan towards renting an electrical saw.  This additional equipment will enhance his business by broadening the range of services he can offer his customers.   


Ham P. is pictured above with his wife, Chan Seoun, who is 47 and works as a farmer. Together, they have three daughters, each working in garment factories and making $120/month.

loans.use: To rent an electrical saw

loans.name: Anne

texts.fr:
Born January 12, 1957 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Mrs. Anne O. is married to Ramane Tidjani, a motorcycle taxi driver in Cotonou. She has five children, including Aziz, a high school senior, and Djemilou and Haniath, high school freshmen. She has lived in Irede, a Cotonou shantytown, for over 20 years, where she has been selling boiled corn paste, firewood and other products. She is requesting this loan because she currently needs financing to increase the size of her business, satisfy her customers and meet her children’s needs in order to provide them with a decent standard of living.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Née le 12 janvier 1957 à COTONOU dans la capitale économique du BENIN, dame O. Anne est mariée à TIDJANI Ramane, conducteur de taxi moto dans la ville de COTONOU et mère de 5 enfants dont Aziz en classe de terminale, Djemilou et Haniath en classe de troisième à sa charge.Elle s’est installée à IREDE un bidonville de COTONOU depuis plus de 20 ans où elle exerce son activité de vente de la pâte de maïs bouilli, des bois de chauffage et autres. Actuellement,elle a besoin de financement pour augmenter le niveau de son activité, satisfaire sa clientèle, pourvoir aux besoins de ses enfants afin d’avoir un niveau de vie acceptable d’où la sollicitation de ce prêt.

loans.use: Purchase of five bags of corn and five bundles of wood

loans.name: Pha

texts.en:
Mrs. Pha Y., age 59, is a widow who owns a plot of farmland growing rice, and normally earns around $1 a day. She has five children, three of whom are married farmers, while two work as garment factory workers. One child still resides with her.

She is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase wood to renovate her house, as in the rainy season she contends with a leaking roof. (Mrs. Pha Y. is pictured with her son and grandson)

loans.use: To purchase wood to renovate her house.

loans.name: En

texts.en: En S. is 34 years old and lives with her husband and one child in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, where she and her spouse are construction workers. On average, both of them earn around $5 a day of profit. However, their transportation to the construction site costs them around one dollar each day for the motor-taxi driver, so to reduce those costs and allow them to save money in the future, they are  requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to commute to work.

loans.name: Aline

texts.fr:
Born around 1971 in Adjaha, in the Mono department in the south of Benin, Mrs. Aline A. is originally from Grand Popo. She is married to Elie Adjinakou, who works at the Postal and Telecommunications Office of Benin, and has two children: Fadil, 14, in fifth grade, and Alabi, 12, in fourth grade. She sells traditional cloth, plastics, oil, soap and other goods. These products are distributed to potential customers but also to other types of customers. Mrs. Aline A. has extensive experience in distribution, but she is currently facing difficulties in supplying all of these products, which are in high demand among her customers. Faced with this situation, she is requesting this loan in order to purchase enough supplies to satisfy her customers.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Née vers les années 1971 à ADJAHA dans le département du MONO au sud du BENIN, dame A. Aline est originaire de GRAND POPO; mariée à ADJINAKOU Elie un agent de l'office des postes télécommunications du BENIN, elle est mère de 2 enfants Fadil 14 ans en classe de CM2 et ALABI 12 ans en classe de CM1. Elle est une revendeuse de pagne, des plastiques, d’huile, des savons et autres. Ces produits font l’objet de distribution vers les clients potentiels mais également vers d’autres types de clients. D’une grande expérience dans la distribution, Dame A. Aline éprouve quelques difficultés actuellement dans l’approvisionnement de ses produits qui font l’objet d’une grande demande auprès de ses clients. Face à cet état de chose, elle sollicite ce crédit pour s’approvisionner afin de satisfaire sa clientèle.

loans.use: Purchase of 10 lengths of cloth, one barrel of oil and 12 basins

loans.name: Meh

texts.en:
Meh S., age 38, is a mother of three children living with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, where she stays at home looking after the children and cooking food for her entire family. Her husband, Ngov Kheng, age 40, is a taxi-driver who normally makes around $10 per day.

Mrs. Meh Sarin and her husband are requesting a loan from Kiva to start another business to increase income for the family. They will use this money to build a stand selling rice and other foods.

loans.use: To open a stand selling rice and food.

loans.name: Inès

texts.fr:
Born September 10, 1977 in Cotonou, Inès Y. is single and lives with her parents. She sells hair extensions, cosmetics, prepaid telephone cards for various GSM cellular phone networks in Benin and other products near her home in Awassa, a working-class neighborhood in Cotonou. Selling telephone cards and other products is becoming increasingly expensive, and she does not have the financial means to purchase these items. She is thus requesting this loan to meet her customers’ demand and expand her business to selling other types of goods.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Née le 10 septembre 1977 à COTONOU, Y. Inès est une femme célibataire vivant avec ses parents. Elle exerce la vente des mèches, des produits de beauté, des cartes de recharge des différents réseaux de téléphonie mobile de type GSM implantés au BENIN et autres à AWASSA un quartier populaire de COTONOU près de son domicile. La vente des cartes de recharges et autres devenant de plus en plus excessive et ne disposant pas de moyens financiers pour l’achat desdits produits, elle sollicite alors ce prêt afin de satisfaire à la demande de sa clientèle et élargir son secteur d’activité vers d’autres types de produits.

loans.use: Purchase of one bale of hair extensions and various cosmetic products

loans.name: Chou

texts.en:
Chou Thou, a 42-year-old widowed farmer who lives in Kompong Cham province in Cambodia, started her business in 1980 and earns approximately $1.50 per day. She lives with her two children, both of whom work as goldsmiths earning around $3 per day.


Chou is requesting a loan to diversify her business by purchasing a horse-drawn cart, which she can use to transport goods between villages.

loans.use: To purchase a horse-drawn cart.

loans.name: Asia

texts.en:
Asia is 22 years old and is married with one child, two years old. Asia is a food seller, a business she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 7am to 4pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $230 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Sorn N., a 68-year-old widow with six children, works as a farmer, earning about $1.50 a day. Three children are married and live away from home and the other three are garment factory workers, earning $50 each per month.

Sorn is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase a cow to assist with the farm work; the remainder will be used to buy another plot of farmland to grow more rice.

loans.use: To purchase a cow and another plot of farmland.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is 30 years old and is married with four children, ages 3, 4, 8 and 10 years. She and her husband also take care of another person, age 60.

Rehema owns a small charcoal store, which she started in 2004. Everyday, she works from 7am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $600 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Naliyama

texts.en:
Naliyama S. is a trader who prepares palm oil for sale. She is married and has 5 dependents. She wants to increase production but lacks capital to enable her to expand her business.

She is asking for $425 as additional capital to invest in her oil production.

loans.use: As additional capital to invest in her oil production

loans.name: Issah

texts.en:
Issah S. is a corn mill operator. He is married and has 2 children. Business is doing very well, and he wants to do some maintenance work on the machine. But his problem is lack of funds.

He is asking for $525 as additional funds to enable him to service his machine.

loans.use: As additional funds to enable him to service his machine

loans.name: Ashibae

texts.en:
Ashibae is a single woman with two children, ages 8 and 2 years. Ashibae is a soap seller, a business she started in 2007. She works from 10am to 2pm each day and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

She hopes for a loan to buy more soap for her business.

loans.use: To buy more soap for her business.

loans.name: Men

texts.en: Men T., 44 years old, lives in the Kompong Chong province of Cambodia. She is a widow with one child. Men T. has been running a small business selling bananas since 1990, and currently makes approximately $1.60 per day. She would like to take out a loan to purchase larger quantities of bananas in bulk so that she can resell them for higher returns at the market.

loans.use: To purchase bananas in bulk for resale

loans.name: Theresia

texts.en:
Theresia is a single woman with one child, aged 10 years. She also take cares of one other person, age 17.

Theresia began her business as a food seller in 2007. Every day, she works from 7.30am to 6.30pm and she can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales. She wants a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Prach

texts.en:
Prach S., aged 32, is a father of two children and lives with his wife in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. He owns a plot of farmland growing rice, earning around $3 a day of income. His wife is a garment worker with a daily income $5 per day. Their two children are students.

He would like a loan from Kiva to purchase a water pump to water his rice crops in the dry season. This will help him to grow rice in both the raining and dry seasons.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump.

loans.name: Hav

texts.en:
Hav S., aged 40, is a true entrepreneur with three children and resides in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband have two businesses to support their standard of living. She is a private tailor and earns around $2 a day. Her husband, Mr. Pov Phal, owns a plot of farmland and works as a farmer growing rice since 1980. On average, he makes $2 a day of profit. They have three children, two of whom are too young to attend the school yet, and one who is a student.

To respond to the growth of the tailoring business, she would like a loan from Kiva to replace the old and unreliable sewing machine. This will provide her more output and enable her to earn more income.

loans.use: To replace the old and unreliable sewing machine.

loans.name: Felister

texts.en:
Felister is 24 years old and is married with one child, age 5. Felister is a charcoal seller, a business she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah N. is a hairdresser. She is a single parent of 3 children. Her income is not sufficient to meet the needs of her family. She wants to improve her services to attract more customers, but she lacks adequate capital.

She is asking for $325 as additional capital to buy hairdressing materials for her salon.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy hairdressing materials for her salon

loans.name: Salamatu

texts.en:
Salamatu S. is a fishmonger. She is married and has 2 dependents. She buys fresh fish from the fishermen, brings it home for processing, and then later sells the fish to her customers. She wants to increase sales to meet the demand of her customers.

She is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more fish for processing and sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more fish for processing and sale

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia S. is a fishmonger. She is a single parent of 1 child. She buys fresh fish from the fishermen, brings it home for processing, and then later sells the fish to her customers. She wants to increase sales to meet the demand of her customers.

She is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more fish for processing and sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more fish for processing and sale

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes A. sells frozen meat. She is married and has 2 children. The business of meat selling is doing very well, and she wants to increase sales to increase her income.

She is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more meat for sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more meat for sale

loans.name: Marifat

texts.ru:
Marifat A. lives in the town of Vahdat. She is 40 years old, married and has five children. She has secondary education. Marifat has a small grocery store at the market near her house. It is very convenient for the residents of the town. She brings in the merchandise from Dushanbe where she buys it wholesale. After she brings in the merchandise, she makes 20-30% profit on sales. This is not a very big income for her family. To increase her profits she needs to increase the commodity circulation and for this she plans to get a loan. By increasing the turnaround she will bring in new customers and satisfy the needs of the locals for reasonable prices. She has around 10 years experience in this field. Marifat plans to pay off the loan within 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Азимова Марифат жительница города Вахдат.Ей 40 лет , замужем ,имеет 5 детей. Образование среднее . Марифат имеет небольшой продуктовый магазин на рынке рядом с домом. Это создает удобства для населения ее села.Привозит товар из города Душанбе, где покупает у оптовых продавцов. После того , как она привозит товар она продает его с прибылью в 20-30% .Это не очень большой доход для ее семьи.Для того , чтобы увеличить доход необходимо увеличить товарооборот.Для этого она планирует получить кредит. Увеличив товарооборот она привлечет новых клиентов и сможет удовлетворить потребности населения по доступным ценам. Опыт в данной сфере уже около 10 лет. Погасить кредит она сможет в течении 10 месяцев.

loans.use: To increase

loans.name: Sochigul

texts.ru:
Sochigul O. lives in the town of Vahdat. She is married and has five children. She has a college education and is a school teacher by profession. Her salary is not enough to feed the family and this is why she is in the retail business. She has a vendor space where she sells food and groceries. She has been in this business for 15 years. Sochigul wants to expand her space and needs the building materials and to increase commodity turnover. She plans to receive a loan which he will pay off within 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Орипова Сочигуль живет в городе Вахдат. Она замужем и имеет 5 детей. Имеет высшее образование. По профессии учитель средней школы. Ее зарплаты не хватает для того , чтобы кормить семью. Поэтому она занимается торговлей. Имеет торговую точку , где продает продукты питания.Занимается торговлей уже 15 лет. Хочет расширить торговую точку. Для этого небходим материал для постройки и увеличить товарооборот.Планирует получить кредит , погасить который сможет в течении 10 миесяцев.

loans.use: To increase the commodity turnover

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is 23 years old and is married. She takes care of one person, aged 32. Amina is a clothes seller, a business she started in 2004. Every day, she works from 6am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more vitenge (clothes) for her business.

loans.use: To buy more vitenge (clothes) for her business.

loans.name: Fayzinisso

texts.ru:
Fayzinisso N. lives in Vahdat. She is married and has six children. She has secondary education. She has a small grocery store at the Vahdat market and has been in this business for more than nine years. Fayzinisso's husband is temporarily unemployed and she has to support her big family on her own. This business is the only source of income for her family. She uses the profits which she makes from the store to buy food for the family. Because Fayzinisso does not have enough of her own money, she decided to take out a loan to increase the variety of merchandise in her store. By adding more products to her store she will increase the profits for her family. She plans to pay off the loan within 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Неъматова Файзиниссо жительница Вахдат. Замужем, имеет 6 детей. Образование средние. На рынке Вахдат имеет магазин, где торгует продуктами питания. Занимается этой деятельностью более 9 лет. Муж Файзиниссо временно не работает. Клиентка сама содержит свою большую семью. Бизнес я вляется единственным источником дохода ее семьи. На прибыль от магазина она покупает необходимые продукты питания для своей семьи. Так как своих денег у нее нет ,Файзиниссо решила взять кредит для увеличения ассортимента своей точки. Пополнив новым товаром магазин она сможет увеличить доход для своей семьи. Планирует погасить кредит в течении 10 месяцев.

loans.use: To increase commodity turnover

loans.name: Sea

texts.en:
Seam S. is a 46-year old widow living in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. She has 6 children, three of whom are married. The other three work as garment workers.

Since 2001, Seam S. has operated a small business selling yams wholesale. With this loan, she would like to purchase additional yams in higher bulk quantities so that she can resell them for greater returns.

loans.use: To purchase yams in bulk for resale

loans.name: Sharifa's Mapatano Group

texts.en:
Sharifa is 27 years old and is married with three children, ages 2-9 years old. Sharifa owns a small food vendor store and she is also a soap seller, businesses she started in 2005. Everyday, she works from 8am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $155 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items and soap for her business. She will share this loan with her sub-group members Rebeca and Veneranda, who have businesses dealing in food vending.

loans.use: To buy more food items and soap for her business.

loans.name: Roth

texts.en: Roth S. is 43 years old and is currently employed by the Banteay Srey organization in Siem Reap. Working for them, she makes 2 US$ per day. Her husband also works in Siem Reap and is employed in manual labor for various projects around town. He can earn 3 US$ per day on average. The couple has five children, one of whom is married. The four children still living in the family home are all working as either construction workers or are laborers like their father. Obviously, with so many family members working in many different places in the same city, transport is an issue. Roth S. wants to buy a motorbike to use to take her family members to work before going in herself.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Hou

texts.en:
Hou S. K., aged 38, is a mother of six children and has lived with her husband in Kampong Cham province for years. She and her husband have different businesses to make the family live easily. She is a vendor in a busy market. She makes bean cakes (made with soybeans) and brings them to sell in the market to earn approximately $3 a day. Her husband, head of the family, has been a rice dealer since 2007. He goes door to door to purchase rice from the customers in his village in order to gather the rice in bulk and resell in large amounts to the rice miller. Normally, he earns around $7 per day of income. They have six children, who are all students.

He would like a loan from Kiva to purchase rice in bulk. This will allow him to save in the future and also have enough money to continue sending his children to school.

loans.use: To purchase rice in bulk.

loans.name: Zuwena

texts.en:
Zuwena is married with one child, age10. Zuwena is a tailor and a clothes seller, selling khanga and vitenge. She started this business in 2002.

Zuwena works from 8am to 11.30pm each day and she can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales. She is applying for a loan to buy more tailoring items and clothes (khanga and vitenge) for her business.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring items and clothes (khanga and vitenge) for her business.

loans.name: Yi

texts.en:
Yi P. is 41 years old and runs a business making and selling Khmer style noodles from her home. She can make around 1.50 US$ per day through this business. Her husband, Teang Tha, has been a construction foreman since the year 2000. In this management position, he earns 5 US$ per day overseeing small scale construction projects throughout Siem Reap.

They have four children who are enrolled in school and help their parents run businesses. As Yi P. already works in the food industry, she would like to branch out into rice farming as well. She wants to purchase a piece of farmland to grow both rice and vegetables on. She hopes to eliminate her family’s food costs by providing for them herself and being able to make a profit with what is left over. Subsistence farming of this kind is common in Cambodia. Rice prices have dramatically increased in recent months, making it difficult for poorer Khmer’s not farming to afford this basic food staple.

loans.use: to purchase farmland.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa is 30 years old and is married with two children, ages 10 and 7. Hawa owns a small food vendor store, which she started in 1999. She works from 8am to 6pm each day, earning a monthly profit of about $120 from her sales.

She hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her food vending business.

loans.name: Preng

texts.en:
Preng C., aged 48, is a widow with one child and lives with her elderly mother in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She has one small business to earn a daily income to support the household. Everyday, she has to go around her village to purchase recyclable items and resell them to the recycling plant. Sometimes, she makes around $3 to $4 a day of profit. Her child is a student.

She would like to request a loan from Kiva to purchase recyclable items in bulk and resell them the recycling plant.

loans.use: To purchase recyclable items in bulk.

loans.name: Muon

texts.en:
Muon Y. is 37 years old. She and her husband raise pigs as livestock from their family home and sell them in the surrounding villages. Their combined income only amounts to 2 US$ per day. Despite their extremely low income, they still manage to send all four of their children to school. This is impressive and no doubt difficult to maintain as most families of the same economic standing often require their children to stay home to avoid education costs, or to work with their parents in the family business.

She wants to purchase more piglets to breed with the ones she is already raising. She will then sell the older pigs to the local butcher where the majority of her profit comes from. It takes four to five months for the piglets to mature and be capable of reproducing.

loans.use: To buy piglets.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 29 years old and is married with one child, aged 15. Mary is a tailor, a business she started in 2003. Every day, she works from 8am to 4pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $120 from her sales.

Mary wants a loan to buy another machine for her business.

loans.use: To buy another machine for her business.

loans.name: Aisha's Amani Group

texts.en:
Aisha is married with a child aged 4 years old. Aisha owns a small food vendor store, which she started in 2001. She works from 12 to 6pm daily at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $240 from her sales.

She wants a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her sub-group member Mariam, who has business dealing in clothes sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Ven

texts.en: Ven R. is 68 years of age and a widow living in Kampong Cham province. She lives with, and is cared for by, one of her daughters, Yon Narem. Yon Narem is 37 years old (pictured here as her mother was unavailable) and farms vegetables, which she sells to the market for about 2 US$ per day. Her other two children are both married and send them some cash each month to help with expenses. Ven R. wants to install water pipes that will help them irrigate their fields; something very rarely done efficiently in Cambodia. This will cost about 100 US$. The remainder of the loan would go towards renting a plot of land nearby on which her daughter will also work.

loans.use: To purchase an irrigation system and rent land.

loans.name: Sum

texts.en:
Sum M., aged 48, is a mother of nine children and owns a plot of farmland where she has been growing rice since 1979. She makes less than one dollar a day. Her husband, Van Nie, aged 50, has a business selling ice-cream in the village. He has a small cart to transport his ice-cream and sell from door to door to earn approximately two dollars of profit per day. Of their nine children, three are married and live away from home, while another three are garment factory workers, earning around $2.50 each per day. Moreover, one another is a construction worker building houses, and normally makes $2 a day. The youngest children are students.

She would like a loan from Kiva to make the ice-cream in large amounts and resell in the village. (Picture: husband and wife)

loans.use: To make more ice-cream to sell.

loans.name: Mwanahawa

texts.en:
Mwanahawa is married with four children, aged 3 to 19 years. Mwanahawa owns a small charcoal store, which she started in 2008. Every day, she works from 8am to 12pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $315 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Pricila

texts.en:
Pricila is widow woman with five children, ages 5-22 years old. Pricila owns a small food store, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $170 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more hot pots for food storage and more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy hot pots for food storage and more food items for her business.

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Ly T. is 27 years old and living in Kampong Cham province. She and her husband got married in the year 2000. With their savings, together they bought a large generator which they use to supply electricity to the local people. Electricity is a precious commodity in rural Cambodia, which exists in an almost constant energy crisis. Cambodian energy suppliers have been unable to produce enough energy to provide power to all of their clients, and daily blackouts have become a part of regular life throughout the country. Consequently, privately owned generators are necessities for small, more isolated villages. They earn 3 to 5 US$ per day through this business.

Ly T. has four children. Two of her children work at a local rubber plantation collecting the sap from which rubber is made. As the family business is secure through the generator, Ly T. wants to expand into farming by buying farmland on which to grow yams.

loans.use: To buy farmland.

loans.name: Asia

texts.en:
Asia is 24 years old, married and has two children, ages 8 and 7. Asia owns a small shop, which she started in 2006. She works at her shop from 8am to 9pm daily and can earn a monthly profit of about $225.

She would use this loan to buy items such as sugar, salt, oil and matches to sell in her shop.

loans.use: To buy more items for a small shop

loans.name: Ven

texts.en: Ven S. is 40 years old and living in Kampong Cham province managing her household and caring for her children who are all still living in the family home.  Her older two children are garment factory workers and the youngest is a student.  Ann Eng, her husband, provides for their family as a motortaxi driver.  His motorbike, however, is old and becoming inoperable.  She wants to provide for her family by purchasing her husband a new motorbike to be used to taxi around clients.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
Jamila is married and has 3 children, ages 13, 8 and 5. Jamila owns a small charcoal store, which she started in 2007. She works at her shop every day from 7am to 6pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $450.

Jamila has requested this loan so that she can buy more charcoal to sell in her shop.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
Miriam is married with 2 children, ages 4 and 1. She started selling fish in 1998. Now, she works every day from 7am to 10pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $225.

She has requested this loan to buy more fish to sell.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en:
Hadija is 42 years old. She is divorced and has 3 children, ages 23, 21 and 17. Hadija owns a small beauty salon, which she started in 2005. She works from 8am to 9pm every day and can earn a monthly profit of about $190.

She has requested this loan to buy more salon items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for a beauty salon

loans.name: Saudat

texts.en:
Saudat is 37 years old. She is divorced and is responsible for taking care of her 3 children, ages 16, 12 and 10. Saudat owns a small food store, which she started in 2006. She works at her shop every day between 7am and 2pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $250.

Saudat has applied for this loan so that she can buy more food items to sell in her shop.

loans.use: To buy more food items to sell in a small shop

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua is 43 years old, and she is the mother of six children, three of whom are currently in school. She has been preparing local dishes like banku (a meal prepared from milled maize), rice balls, and ampesie (boiled yams, plantains, or cocoyams eaten with cabbage or soy bean sauce) for the past thirteen years. Through the success of her operations, she has been able to register to join the National Health Insurance Scheme, where she can now access free medical care for herself and for her children.

Akua is seeking a loan to buy more bags of rice, maize, fresh yams, plantains, and vegetables to enable her stay active in business and to avoid price hikes during the lean season.

She is a member of the group called Alpha and Omega. The group members agree in principle to guarantee each other as social collateral to insure that their fellow group members repay their respective loans.

loans.use: To remain profitable and to avoid rising prices by purchasing additional food products (e.g., rice, maize, fresh yams, and plantains) in bulk.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna is 47 years old. She is a widow with 5 children between the ages of 11 and 18. Anna owns a small food store, which she started in 2006. She works at her shop from 7am to 7pm every day and earns a monthly profit of around $190 from her sales.

Anna would use this loan to buy more products to sell in her shop.

loans.use: To buy more food items for a small shop

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda is 47 years old, married and has 7 children between the ages of 14 and 27. Imelda owns a small clothes shop, which she started in 2005. She works at her shop from 7am to 9pm every day earns a monthly profit of about $400 from her sales.

Imelda has requested this loan so that she can buy more clothes to sell in her shop.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama is a young, 22-year-old woman. She has been cooking pasta, rice, and vegetable sauce for the past 2.5 years. In addition to her food sales, she sells soft drinks such as Coke, Fanta, and Sprite. Because she sells her food and drinks at the main town’s lorry station, there is always a high demand for her products.

She is seeking a loan to buy more boxes of pasta, crates of eggs, vegetables, and crates of soft drinks in order to expand her operations.

Ama is a member of the group called Alpha and Omega. Group members apply positive peer pressure on each other as social collateral to insure that fellow group members repay their respective loans in a timely manner.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional food products (e.g., boxes of pasta and crates of eggs) and soft drinks

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is married and has a 7 year old child. She started selling clothes in 2007. She works from 7am to 7pm every day and earns a monthly profit of about $250.

Lydia plans to use this loan to buy more clothes to sell in her shop.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is married woman with 1 child, age 7 years old. Lydia is a clothes seller, she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 7am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for business.

loans.name: Vida

texts.en:
Vida is 25 years old, and she is the mother of a 1.5-year-old baby boy. She prepares and sells breakfast meals, including hot cocoa drinks, lipton tea, bread with scramble eggs, etc., and her business serves as the main lorry station within her village to travelers.

She is very happy to operate such a business and she sees the potential to earn a good deal of income from her operations. At present, she is seeking a loan to buy more products such as cocoa powder, milo, lipton tea, crates of eggs, and vegetableS in order to expand her operations.

Vida is a member of the group called Alpha and Omega. Group members agree in principle to guarantee each other as social collateral to repay their respective loans on time.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional food products such as cocoa powder, milo, milk, sugar, and eggs.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 36 years old and married. She and her husband also take care of one other person who is 33 years old. Jane runs a small electronics shop, which she started in 2004. She works from 7am to 10pm every day and earns a monthly profit of about $225.

Jane would use this loan to buy more electronics items for her shop.

loans.use: To buy more electronics items for a successful shop

loans.name: Rosina

texts.en:
Rosina is a 43-year-old mother of seven children, all of whom are currently in school. She sells various food products like frozen fish, frozen beef, frozen chicken thighs, and garden eggs, as well charcoal, which is the main source of fire for cooking in the majority of Ghanaian homes.

She would like to provide her children with a high-quality education, so she is seeking a loan to buy more bags of charcoal, crates, frozen food products, and the like in order to generate additional income.

She is member of the group called “Eye Yehowa” (meaning, "it is God"). Group members happily guarantee each other as social collateral to repay their respective loans.

loans.use: To generate additional income so that she can provide her children with a high-quality education by purchasing additional food products (e.g., frozen fish and meats, garden eggs, crates of tomatoes, and cartons of tin fish) and charcoal

loans.name: Habiba

texts.en:
Habiba S. prepares palm oil for sale. She is married and has 4 children. She wants more raw materials to increase production and sales.

She is asking for $425 as additional capital to buy more raw materials for oil production and sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more raw materials for oil production and sale

loans.name: Sawudatu

texts.en:
Sawudatu M. prepares food for sale. She is married and has 4 children. Business is doing very well, and customers are increasing.

She is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more food stuffs to increase production.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more food stuffs to increase production

loans.name: Abaya

texts.en:
Abaya Z. prepares palm oil for sale. She is married and has 3 children. She wants to buy more raw materials to increase production.

She is asking for $225 as additional capital to enable her to buy more raw materials for oil production and sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to enable her to buy more raw materials for oil production and sale

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is married, and she is the mother of three children, all of whom are currently in school. She sells frozen foods such as chicken, fish, and beef, but she also sells charcoal (the main source of fire for cooking purposes in the majority of Ghanaian homes) to generate additional income for her family.

Elizabeth is seeking a loan to buy more frozen products and bags of charcoal in order to expand her operation and to avoid price hikes on the products that she purchases. Further, she believes that the loan proceeds will allow her to generate sufficient income to allow her to start saving money towards her children’s school fees and other such needs.

She is a member of the group called Genesis. Group members agree in principle to guarantee each other as social collateral to repay their respective loans.

loans.use: To expand her business and to avoid increasing product prices by purchasing food (e.g., chicken, fish, and beef) and food preparation products (namely, charcoal) in bulk.

loans.name: Abiodun

texts.en: Abiodun O. is a mother of 3. She is 32 years of age and hails from Ayetor, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells wine, juice and other drinks. Abiodun acquired her skill for 10 years and has been in her business for the past 5 years. She is in need of a loan of $850 to enable her buy more wine, juice and other drinks for re-sale. This, she said, will help her increase her profit.

loans.use: To buy more wine, juice, and other drinks

loans.name: Memuna

texts.en:
Memuna S. is a fishmonger. She is married and has 6 dependents. She buys fresh fish from the fishermen, brings it home for processing, and then later sells the fish to her customers. She wants to increase sales to meet the demand of her customers.

She is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more fish for processing and sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more fish for processing and sale

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en:
Akosua is 44 years old, and she is married with four children, all of whom are in school. She sells smoked fish, canned tomatoes, plain rice, beans, and spices in her village.

Akssua is seeking a loan to buy more bags of rice, bags of beans, cartons of fish to smoke, and some spices to expand her business and to avoid the constantly rising prices of her products. In turn, she is hopeful that the loan proceeds will enable her to increase her sales and thereby allow her to generate sufficient income so that she may register for the National Health Insurance Scheme.

She is a member of the group called “Sunkwa” (meaning, "think of Life"). Group members agree in principle to guarantee each other as a form of social collateral to insure that they repay their respective loans.

loans.use: To expand her business and to avoid increasing product prices by purchasing various food products (e.g., cartons of fish, bags of rice, bags of beans, etc.) in bulk

loans.name: Gifty

texts.en:
Gifty A. sells used clothing and other items. She is married and has 2 children. Business is doing very well, and she wants to increase sales but lacks enough capital.

She is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more goods for sale

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en:
Augustina is a 72-year-old widow with six children and twenty grandchildren. She has been selling onions, salt, and garden eggs for the past twenty years. Due to her age, she has to rely on other traders to buy and sell her products in bulk to customers; even so, she still sells some of her products on her own on a table-top in the local market to maintain her physical strength.

Augustina is seeking a loan to buy more bags of onions, sacks of salt, and garden eggs.

She is a member of the group called “Sunkwa” (meaning, "think of Life"). Group members agree in principle to guarantee each other as social collateral to repay their respective loans.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional food products (e.g., onions, salt, and garden eggs).

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
Dora is 41 years old, and she is the mother of five children, all of whom are in school. She has been selling grocery products for two years, and she has recently added certain products such as fresh pineapples, plantains, and cocoyams to her business's inventory. While she sells her foodstuffs in the local city where she is able to generate considerable sales, she has to buy her grocery products from Accra and the foodstuffs from another nearby village.

As such, Dora is seeking a loan to buy more bags of pineapple, sacks of plantains, and cocoyams, as well as other groceries such as canned tomatoes, canned fish, soap, and evaporated milk.

She is a member of the group called “Eye Yehowa” (meaning, "it is God"). Group members exert positive peer pressure on each other as social collateral to encourage the group members to promptly repay their respective loans.

loans.use: To expand her inventory by purchasing additional food and grocery products (e.g., pineapple, cocoyams, and plantains).

loans.name: Ama Atta

texts.en:
Ama Atta H. sells cooking utensils. She is a single parent with 6 dependents. Her income is not sufficient to meet the needs of her family. She wants to increase sales to improve her income.

She is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more goods for sale

loans.name: Nasra

texts.en:
Nasra is 24 years old, married, and has a 5 year old child. Nasra owns a small food shop, which she started in 2006. Every day she works from 8am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of $190 from her sales.

Nasra has applied for this loan so that she can buy more products (such as soda, salt, sugar and juice) for her shop.

loans.use: To buy more items (e.g. soda, salt, soap, sugar and juice) to sell

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Farida is 39 years old and is a widow with 3 children, ages 20, 16 and 12. Farida owns a small food store, which she started in 2000. Every day Farida works from 7am to 7pm at her shop and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Farida has requested this loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items to sell

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina S. sells clothing. She is married and has 1 child. Business is doing very well, and she wants to increase sales to meet the demand of her customers.

She is asking for $325 for additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loans.use: For additional capital to buy more goods for sale
